name: Secure Remote Access
description: In the previous topic, you learned about cloud networking fundamentals, including VPCs, subnets, and traffic flow. Now, the focus is on understanding secure remote access mechanisms that protect cloud resources from unauthorized access.

learning_steps.description: Modern cloud security recommends session-based access over direct SSH/RDP connections. These services provide audit logging, don't require opening SSH ports, and integrate with your cloud IAM.

options.title: AWS Systems Manager Session Manager
options.description: Connect to your instances without SSH keys or open ports

options.title: Azure Bastion
options.description: Secure RDP/SSH connectivity to your VMs directly in the Azure portal

options.title: GCP Identity-Aware Proxy
options.description: Official guide to using IAP for secure access to GCP resources

learning_steps.description:
Advantages over direct SSH/RDP:

• No exposed SSH ports (port 22/3389) on security groups
• Integrated with cloud IAM - use your existing identity
• Full audit logging of all sessions
• No need to manage SSH keys
• Browser-based access - no local SSH client needed

learning_steps.title: AWS Session Manager vs SSH
learning_steps.description: AWS best practices for connecting to EC2 instances using Session Manager

Complete these secure access exercises:

1. Configure session-based access for remote servers using AWS SSM, Azure Bastion, or GCP IAP
2. Apply IAM policies to enforce least privilege access for remote users
3. Test connecting to a VM without using traditional SSH
4. Review the audit logs generated by your session

questions.prompt: Walk me through why session-based access like AWS SSM or Azure Bastion is preferred over direct SSH access.
What security benefits does a cloud-native remote access solution provide over traditional methods?

test_knowledge_prompts: Can you explain the different secure remote access methods in cloud environments?
Can you quiz me on the advantages of using session-based access (AWS SSM, Azure Bastion, GCP IAP) instead of direct SSH/RDP?
Can you explain why we don't want to expose port 22 or 3389 on our security groups?
